so: Review of CBC, Chem panel, and urinalysis submitted on 12/21.  Red blood cell count is slightly elevated.  MCV is slightly decreased and MCHC is very slightlyl above reference range.  MCV and MCHC values are consistent with previous values.  Chemistry panel shows mild decreases in sodium, potassium, and chloride.  Urinalysis is wnl.
a: Elevated red blood cell count may sugges dehydration.  Microcytosis may be suggestive of chronic disease in this animal.  Electrolyte abnormalities likely secondary to chronic diarrhea in this animal.
p: Animal is currently on treatment with injectable antibiotics.  Reports of diarrhea have continued.  Continue treatment and continue to monitor animal daily.  Consider rechecking bloodwork at TB testing if signs persist.  cc
Description: so: Review of CBC, Chem panel, and urinalysis submitted on 12/21.  Red blood cell count is slightly elevated.  MCV is slightly decreased and MCHC is very slightlyl above reference range.  MCV and MCHC values are consistent with previous values.  Chemistry panel shows mild decreases in sodium, potassium, and chloride.  Urinalysis is wnl., a: Elevated red blood cell count may sugges dehydration.  Microcytosis may be suggestive of chronic disease in this animal.  Electrolyte abnormalities likely secondary to chronic diarrhea in this animal., p: Animal is currently on treatment with injectable antibiotics.  Reports of diarrhea have continued.  Continue treatment and continue to monitor animal daily.  Consider rechecking bloodwork at TB testing if signs persist.  cc

so: CBC from 7/10 shows thrombocytopenia with platelet aggregates and a normal wbc count with eosinophilia.  chemistry panel is wnl.  weight within normal range.
a: eosinophilia occasional sign in this animal, could indicate allergy or parasitic response, although nothing present in history or on PE to confirm this.  platelet count artificially low because of presence of aggregates.
p: continue to monitor bloodwork twice yearly.  MH
Description: so: CBC from 7/10 shows thrombocytopenia with platelet aggregates and a normal wbc count with eosinophilia.  chemistry panel is wnl.  weight within normal range., a: eosinophilia occasional sign in this animal, could indicate allergy or parasitic response, although nothing present in history or on PE to confirm this.  platelet count artificially low because of presence of aggregates., p: continue to monitor bloodwork twice yearly.  MH

so: reported for vaginal prolapse.  about 2 cm of vagina is prolapsed.  animal observed urinating while vagina was prolapsed  sedated to replace prolapse.  T=99.7, HR=174, RR=24.  vaginal mucosa slightly dry and not edematous.  grade 2/6 left basal systolic murmur.  dental extraction sites healed.  uterus about 2 cm in diameter and firm.  sedation and recovery uneventful.
a: vaginal prolapse.  may be related to persistent mens. (mens. reported for past 5 of 6 days) and endometriosis.  uterus appears to be responding to medroxyprogesterone acetate as it is much smaller than previously.
p: lavaged prolapsed tissue with 0.9% NaCl.  replaced prolapse and placed purse string suture using 3-0 vicryl.  placed heat lamp on cage to help recovery.  recheck tomorrow.  MH
Description: so: reported for vaginal prolapse.  about 2 cm of vagina is prolapsed.  animal observed urinating while vagina was prolapsed  sedated to replace prolapse. (mens. reported for past 5 of 6 days) and endometriosis.  uterus appears to be responding to medroxyprogesterone acetate as it is much smaller than previously., p: lavaged prolapsed tissue with 0.9% NaCl.  replaced prolapse and placed purse string suture using 3-0 vicryl.  placed heat lamp on cage to help recovery.  recheck tomorrow.  MH

so: Review of complete history by behavior management and veterinary staff.  History of frequent, often severe wounding events in this singly housed male.  In September 2004, animal was first noted to have minor wounds from fighting with partner.  Multiple minor wounding events over the next year ultimately resulted in the separation of this pair in August 2005.  Multiple attempts were made to pair this animal with other conspecifics and were unsuccesful due to aggression by this male.  Animal has been singly housed since 8-31-2005.  First self-wounding event may have been as early as 7-11-2007 but event was poorly documented.  Another event reported in January 2008 and then in April 2008.  Frequent self-wounding events began in July 2008.  Initially wounding events occurred at 2-4 week intervals; frequency began increasing dramatically in October 2008.  Targets include primarily the upper arms but also occasionally the legs.  Animal received BCG vaccinations in July 2008.  Distribution and timing of SIB is inconsistent with vaccine reaction.  Wounding events do not seem to correlate with cage washing, sedations, or changes in care staff on that floor.  In October, animal began receiving additional foraging opportunities.  Increased frequency of wounding noted in November after moving to room a260, where animal is currently housed.
a: Escalating self-wounding events may be related to housing location.  Staff reports observed antagonism between this animal and two other specific animals in that room (cy0165 and r01022).   Wounds have been quite severe; concerned about possible escalation of injurious behavior.
p: Relocate this animal to a quiet room without any overly-dominant males.  Place in cage away from door to minimize disruptions to this animal.  Monitor closely for changes in attitude or presence of new wounds.  If wounding events continue, need to consider alternative intervention.  Pharmacologic intervention will be warranted if relocation does not alleviate wounding.  Animal will continue to receive additional foraging opportunities from behavior management staff.  cc/js
Description: so: Review of complete history by behavior management and veterinary staff.  History of frequent, often severe wounding events in this singly housed male.  In September 2004, animal was first noted to have minor wounds from fighting with partner.  Multiple minor wounding events over the next year ultimately resulted in the separation of this pair in August 2005. so: Animal re-paired with partner r02116.
a: Animal had been separated from partner to evaluate SIB.  Trial separation did not appear to reduce instances of SIB.  Upon re-pairing pair had good proximity and were sharing treats.  r02135 was fighting with neighboring animal through the front of the cage.  Other animal relocated in attempt to eliminate this behavior.  Animal observed self biting several times after looking at self in mirror.  Mirror will be permanently removed from cage in attempt to reduce SIB.
p: Continue to monitor.  Consider weekly monitoring for SIB if behavior increases in frequency or severity.  MR
Description: so: Animal re-paired with partner r02116., a: Animal had been separated from partner to evaluate SIB.  Trial separation did not appear to reduce instances of SIB.
